No physical evidence was ever found to support McCullough's conviction.

Two studies conducted by researchers at the University of California, San Diego have revealed new insights into the harmful effects of cigarette smoke on the human body, specifically in relation to antibiotic-resistant bacteria known as MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). The first study, published in the journal Infection and Immunity, found that cigarette smoke enhances the virulence of MRSA by making it more resistant to antibiotics and more aggressive in infecting human cells. The study also showed that cigarette smoke impairs the immune system's ability to fight off MRSA infections.

The second study, published in the journal mBio, found that cigarette smoke functions as a warning signal to MRSA, alerting the bacteria to the presence of a host and triggering it to produce more toxins and become more virulent. The researchers discovered that cigarette smoke contains a compound called acrolein, which binds to a specific receptor on MRSA cells and triggers a response that increases the production of toxins and makes the bacteria more resistant to antibiotics.

Both studies highlight the importance of avoiding cigarette smoke to prevent the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria and to improve overall health. The researchers emphasized that more research is needed to fully understand the complex interactions between cigarette smoke and MRSA and to develop new strategies for preventing and treating MRSA infections.

Overall, these studies add to the growing body of evidence on the harmful effects of cigarette smoke on human health and underscore the importance of smoking cessation programs and public health initiatives to reduce smoking rates and promote healthier lifestyles.
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

Lastly, a team of researchers from Indiana University and the University of California, Irvine, conducted a study to determine the most influential scholar in history. Using a different method than Eom's team, the researchers found that Karl Marx was the most influential scholar, based on the number of citations in academic papers. answers: Using methods borrowed from Google, a group of researchers has analyzed all Wikipedia pages and determined that, at least on the English language version of the site, Frank Sinatra is the world's most important person. Second place goes to Michael Jackson, and third to Pope Pius XII. When factoring in all 24 language editions of the online encyclopedia, the team found that Adolf Hitler ranked the most important person, while Michael Jackson was again second and Madonna third, reports the Guardian. "Our analysis shows that most important historical figures across Wikipedia language editions are born in western countries after the 17th century, and are male," the authors write. The researchers combined two algorithms to reach these conclusions. First, Google's PageRank algorithm, which determines a page's importance based on how many other pages link to it. In using PageRank on Wikipedia, the most important person in the world was 18th-century Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus, likely because the pages of organism after organism link back to the "father of taxonomy." So the researchers added an algorithm called CheiRank, which determines importance based on the number of outgoing links, the thought being that an important person would himself be connected to other important people, things, and events. Using the two together—an approach they dubbed 2DRank—no one beat out Frank Sinatra on English pages or Adolf Hitler across all language versions. Last year, in a separate study analyzing academic references, one team deemed Karl Marx to be the world's most important scholar, according to the Smithsonian. (Click to read about one of Sinatra's quirks.)

In the first case, a woman identified as Jane Doe fell to her death while attempting to navigate down Snowdonia's Tryfan peak with her husband. The couple, who were both experienced climbers, had decided against summiting due to weather conditions and instead opted to find a safer route down. Using a smartphone app and a paper map, they attempted to traverse the west face of the mountain. However, Jane slipped and fell approximately 100 feet, resulting in her death. The inquest recorded an accidental death verdict.

In the second incident, another experienced climber, also named Jane Doe, fell to her death while descending the north face of Snowdonia's Tryfan peak. This Jane Doe and her husband had also decided against summiting due to weather conditions and instead opted for a safer route down. They used a smartphone app and a paper map to navigate their way down the mountain. However, Jane slipped and fell approximately 300 feet, resulting in her death. The inquest also recorded an accidental death verdict.

Both incidents highlighted the importance of proper preparation, navigation skills, and weather awareness when engaging in mountain activities. The use of technology, such as smartphone apps and paper maps, can be helpful but should not replace proper preparation and experience. The inquests also emphasized the need for clear communication and teamwork between climbers.

The incidents also sparked a larger conversation about the use of technology in outdoor activities and the importance of balancing the benefits of technology with the potential risks. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) urged climbers to prioritize safety over technology and to always carry a map and compass, even when using GPS devices.

In both cases, the climbers were described as fit and experienced, having engaged in mountain activities for several years. They had completed marathons and other endurance events, and the inquests noted that their deaths were unexpected and shocking to their families and friends.

The inquests concluded with a reminder to all mountain goers to prioritize safety, prepare thoroughly, and be aware of changing weather conditions. The families of the deceased were offered condolences and support.
answers: A hiker's fatal fall in March has been blamed on using a smartphone app map instead of an actual map. The BBC reports Jane Wilson and her husband Gary were hiking on Tryfan in Wales when it started to get dark and they decided to skip the summit. While attempting to descend the mountain, Gary was looking at an Ordnance Survey app while Jane went a short way ahead to make sure the path was safe, according to the Telegraph. The Manchester Evening News reports Gary heard his wife fall, got to safety, and called for help. Rescuers found the 53-year-old librarian's body at the bottom of a 30-foot cliff with a fractured skull. At a hearing Friday, Jane's was ruled an accidental death due, in part, to using an app instead of a map. "Apart from potential difficulties caused by poor detail on an electronic map, batteries on mobile phones have a nasty habit of running out just when you need them most," the Telegraph quotes a spokesperson for Mountain Rescue England and Wales as saying. A detective says the app map "would have been small and not as detailed" and took the couple on a route that was not the safest. A director with Ordnance Survey says hikers should always use the app in conjunction with an actual map "due to the nature of mobile devices when navigating the real world." Authorities also say Jane wasn't wearing appropriate footwear for the hike. (Go inside the futile search for "Inchworm" on the trail.)

answers: "That new soda tax in Seattle is working out about as well as Chicago's," proclaims a headline at Hot Air. It's not a compliment. The tax, which went into effect Jan. 1, slaps an additional 1.75 cents on each fluid ounce of sugar-sweetened drinks, a group that includes soda, sports drinks, and kombucha. That's nearly double the one-cent levy the Chicago-encompassing Cook County tried, a tax it repealed after about two months. The Chicago Tribune reported at the time that Costco's nine affected locations saw their sales of beverages impacted by the tax fall 34%, while sales jumped 38% at locations just beyond the county line. And Costco is again at the fore of what's happening: Because bulk purchases contain significantly more ounces than an individual one, the impact is starker, as KIRO discovered when it spotted an updated Costco sign for Gatorade in Seattle. The sign details Costco's price for the 35-pack of 16-ounce bottles—$15.99—and separately lists the city's $10.34 tax, for a new total of $26.33. But that's not all the sign says: It also directs consumers to nearby locations that are outside city limits and exempt from the tax. The tax is meant to fight obesity and raise funds for worthy expenditures, but the blog for Citizens Against Government Waste sees the ends quite differently: "Let’s be clear. Soda taxes don’t make people healthier. They don't raise revenue—they drive it outside city limits. They don’t help ease inequality—they make the poor poorer." But some in government seemingly remain hopeful: KXLY reports a bill was reintroduced Monday that would push the tax statewide. (Speaking of Seattle and beverages, the world's largest Starbucks is no longer located there.)

Two recent studies have raised concerns about the safety of acetaminophen, the most commonly used pain reliever during pregnancy. According to the first report from the University of California, Los Angeles, researchers found that pregnant women who frequently used acetaminophen during pregnancy may increase the risk of their children developing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and other behavioral problems. The second study, published in the journal JAMA Pediatrics, revealed that acetaminophen use during pregnancy could be linked to ADHD and other neurodevelopmental disorders in children.

The UCLA study, which analyzed data from over 145,000 mother-child pairs, found that pregnant women who used acetaminophen for more than 20 days during pregnancy had a 29% increased risk of having a child with behavioral problems. The researchers also noted that the risk was higher for children whose mothers used acetaminophen for pain relief rather than fever reduction.

The second study, led by researchers at the University of Cincinnati, analyzed data from over 28,000 children and found that those whose mothers used acetaminophen during pregnancy had a higher risk of developing ADHD and other neurodevelopmental disorders. The researchers also noted that the risk was higher for children whose mothers used acetaminophen in the third trimester of pregnancy.

Despite these findings, the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) maintains that acetaminophen is still the safest pain reliever for pregnant women. However, both studies suggest that pregnant women should avoid using acetaminophen for extended periods and consider alternative methods for pain relief, such as massage, warm baths, and acupuncture.

The studies have not yet established a definitive link between acetaminophen use during pregnancy and neurodevelopmental disorders. Further research is needed to confirm the findings and determine the exact risk factors. In the meantime, pregnant women are advised to consult their healthcare providers before using any pain relievers and to explore non-pharmacological options for managing pain and discomfort.
answers: The bad news about acetaminophen just keeps on coming: A new study finds that use of the drug during pregnancy is linked to "ADHD-like behavioral problems" in children, CNN reports. The Danish study looked at data from more than 64,000 children and found that those who had prenatal exposure to acetaminophen had a 13% higher risk of exhibiting ADHD-like behaviors, a 29% higher risk of being prescribed ADHD medication, and a 37% higher risk of receiving a diagnosis of hyperkinetic disorder, a severe form of ADHD, USA Today reports. The risk increased the later in pregnancy the drug was taken and the longer it was taken. Women who used acetaminophen for 20 weeks or longer had a 50% higher chance of their children being prescribed ADHD medication. But the authors did not find a cause-and-effect relationship, and they note that "exhibiting ADHD-like behaviors" is not the same as actually having ADHD. Right now, doctors consider acetaminophen the "safest" pain reliever for pregnant women, NBC News reports; the study author says pregnant women "shouldn't worry at this point." What could account for the link? The authors think acetaminophen may interfere with key maternal hormones that impact fetal brain development. Another recent study also found that frequent acetaminophen use during pregnancy was linked with a 70% higher risk of behavioral problems in children.

Reporting in the New England Journal of Medicine, researchers say they followed nearly 10,000 men and women with CHD between the ages of 35 and 75 for about five years, monitoring changes in body weight and other health outcomes. The takeaway? "It's important to lose weight, but this data says you have to keep it off," lead researcher Dr. Sripal Bangalore at the New York University School of Medicine tells the New York Times. The highest weight fluctuation was on average 8.6 pounds over five years, while the smallest body weight changes averaged closer to two pounds, reports Medical News Today. Those who were already overweight or obese at the beginning of the study and who experienced the highest level of weight fluctuation experienced 124% more deaths, 136% more strokes, and 117% more heart attacks, meaning these CHD patients were more than twice as likely to suffer these negative outcomes in just a few years than people with CHD whose weight only fluctuated two pounds. This doesn't pinpoint a cause, as pre-existing heart problems could be the culprit, but researchers hope to study this correlation further. (Yo-yo dieting is bad for women's hearts in general.)

In recent news, there have been significant discoveries and advancements in the fields of archaeology and human evolution. According to reports in Science, researchers have unearthed ancient tools and artifacts in Kenya that suggest our ancestors were more technologically advanced than previously believed. The findings, published in the journal Science, indicate that our ancestors were making stone tools around 3.3 million years ago, much earlier than previously thought. These tools were discovered at a site called Lomekwi, and they include flint flakes, cores, and other stone tools.

Furthermore, a team of researchers from the University of Colorado Boulder and the University of California, Berkeley, have published a study in the journal Science suggesting that dramatic climate shifts may have played a role in shaping human behavior and culture. The researchers analyzed data from more than 1,000 archaeological sites across Africa and found that periods of climate instability coincided with the emergence of new technologies and cultural practices.

In other news, a team of researchers from the University of Cambridge and the Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History have discovered evidence of a "human revolution" that occurred much earlier than previously thought. The researchers analyzed data from archaeological sites in Europe and Africa and found that the emergence of modern human behavior, such as the use of symbolic language and complex social structures, occurred around 500,000 years ago. This challenges the traditional view that modern human behavior emerged suddenly around 40,000 years ago.

Finally, a team of researchers from the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge have discovered evidence of ancient human migration out of Africa around 100,000 years ago. The researchers analyzed DNA from modern humans and compared it to DNA from ancient bones found in Europe and Asia. They found that there were multiple waves of human migration out of Africa, and that these migrations occurred much earlier than previously thought.

Overall, these discoveries and advancements in archaeology and human evolution provide new insights into the history of our species and challenge long-held assumptions about when and how modern human behavior emerged.
answers: For decades, the human story was one told through signs of modernity—art, tools, burials—found only after Homo sapiens left Africa. Recent discoveries pushing back the date of departure are helping to change that narrative, as are three new studies in Science. Together, they describe the earliest stone tools of their kind in East Africa as well as the earliest evidence for long-distance transport of raw materials in the region, per Science News. Researchers previously believed the Early Stone Age marked by large, primitive tools (hand axes and cleavers) made way for the Middle Stone Age and its smaller tools (spearpoints and blades) around 280,000 years ago. But stone tools found in Kenya's Olorgesailie Basin show hominin groups—it's not clear which species is responsible—had developed these more advanced tools approximately 320,000 years ago. "We see a smaller technology, a more diverse series of stone tools … designed for specific purposes," researcher Rick Potts tells NPR. An expert not involved in the study says the tools are so "prepared and retouched" they suggest the Middle Stone Age likely started even earlier. What drove it? Microscopic and chemical analyses of the region's soil show the landscape was rapidly shifting between wet and dry conditions, meaning hominins might have been forced to adapt. But as the technology also coincides with the emergence of Homo sapiens in Africa, it's possible that the human mind deserves credit. The tools themselves suggest the development of trading networks, too. Some were made of rocks carried from 55 miles away, says Potts. Others were made of obsidian from as far as 30 miles away, per the Conversation. (These stone tools are also making waves.)

The search for Flight 370 has been a complex and challenging operation due to the vast search area and the limited information available about the plane's last known location. The discovery of the signal is a significant development in the search for Flight 370, but it is important to note that it is not yet confirmed that the signal is definitively from the missing plane. answers: Could it be? A Chinese ship searching for Flight 370 has picked up a ping in the southern Indian Ocean, reports CNN and the BBC. Both cite a report in China's Xinhua news agency. "It is yet to be established whether it is related to the missing jet," the report says. The development comes as dozens of ships and planes intensify their sweeps in the search zone, given the finite battery life of the data recorders.

The ECJ upheld a decision by the European Intellectual Property Office (EUIPO) to reject Nestlé's application for an EU trademark on the shape of the Kit Kat bar. The decision comes after a decade-long dispute with Cadbury, a Mondelez-owned British company, which argued that the shape of the Kit Kat bar was not distinctive enough to be granted trademark protection. The ECJ agreed, stating that the shape of the Kit Kat bar does not have a "distinctive character" that goes beyond the "common shape of the confectionery products in question." The ruling could potentially impact other food and beverage companies that have applied for trademarks based on the shape of their products.

Meanwhile, in a separate legal battle, the ECJ has dismissed appeals by both Nestlé and Mondelez in a dispute over the use of the color purple in Cadbury's Dairy Milk chocolate bars. The case stems from a 2013 application by Nestlé to register the color purple as a trademark for its own chocolate products in the EU. Cadbury objected, arguing that the color purple was synonymous with its Dairy Milk brand. The ECJ ruled in favor of Cadbury, stating that the color purple had become "identified with the specific product" of Cadbury's Dairy Milk chocolate and that Nestlé's application was therefore not valid.

Both cases have significant implications for intellectual property law in the EU and could potentially impact the strategies of other food and beverage companies seeking to protect their brands and products. The ECJ's rulings are final and binding, and both Nestlé and Mondelez have the option to appeal to the European Court of Human Rights. However, such an appeal would be a lengthy and costly process.
answers: "Four trapezoidal bars aligned on a rectangular base" may not be instantly recognizable. Nestle, which makes KitKats, has been fighting Cadbury (and then Mondelez, which ultimately bought Cadbury) in the courts for more than a decade on this issue. The BBC notes that Nestle first applied for trademark protection for the candy's shape in 2002, and it was granted that protection four years later. Cadbury's pushback began in 2007, and Wednesday's decision by the European Court of Justice essentially tells the EU trademark office it now has to "reconsider" its original decision. What that means, however, is that if the EU Intellectual Property Office finds, based on more recent evidence, that the KitKat bar's shape is recognizable in enough countries, it can retain the trademark protection, per Reuters. The brand name itself of "KitKat" is not being contested. (Atari accused Nestle of ripping off one of its popular video games in an ad for KitKat.)

This conclusion was drawn from the discovery of fossilized feathers in dinosaur fossils.

Furthermore, research on the T. rex's roar has been debunked. A team of scientists used computer simulations to recreate the sounds that the T. rex's vocal cords could have produced based on its anatomy. The results showed that the dinosaur's vocal cords were too small to produce the deep, powerful roars commonly heard in movies. Instead, the scientists suggest that the T. rex may have made quieter, guttural sounds.

Another study, published in the journal Science, found that the T. rex and other dinosaurs may have had feathers. The researchers discovered fossilized feathers in the fossilized bones of several dinosaur species, including the T. rex. This discovery challenges the long-held belief that dinosaurs were entirely scaly creatures.

Lastly, a study published in the journal Evolutionary Biology suggests that some dinosaurs may have had closed beaks, which could have muffled their vocalizations. This theory is based on the anatomy of modern birds, which have a similar structure in their beaks. The researchers suggest that this could explain why dinosaur vocalizations have not been preserved in the fossil record.

Overall, these studies challenge the popular perception of dinosaurs and provide new insights into their appearance and vocalizations. The findings suggest that dinosaurs were more complex creatures than previously thought, with a range of vocalizations and possibly even feathers.
answers: Dinosaurs may have been much more like modern birds than we knew—and not just because some had feathers. A new study suggests that mighty dinosaurs of yore didn't roar, contrary to every dinosaur movie you've ever seen. Instead, they made a decidedly less scary sound called a "closed-mouth vocalization." Think of a dove cooing or perhaps an ostrich doing this grunting thing. As the scientists explain in the journal Evolution, per UT News, the sound actually comes out of the neck area after air is pushed through an esophageal pouch. In fact, the animal's mouth is shut the whole time. Lots of birds do this today, and because birds descended from dinosaurs, scientists suspect they may have communicated in a similar way. The fossil record can't prove it, though the Washington Post notes that previous research meshes with the idea, including the belief that dinosaurs had air sacs instead of vocal chords. “A cool thing about this work is the demonstration that closed-mouth behavior evolved many times,” says the lead author. “That suggests it can emerge fairly easily and be incorporated into mating displays" among different types of animals. A co-author says the study gives the impression of "a very different Jurassic world. Not only were dinosaurs feathered, but they may have had bulging necks and made booming, closed-mouth sounds." But if so, the makers of Jurassic Park didn't get it all wrong: The hiss of the film's velociraptors came from a goose, per Vulture. (Scientists have grown chickens with dinosaur legs.)

The military council, which has been ruling Egypt since Mubarak's resignation, has faced increasing pressure to transfer power to a civilian government. The parliamentary elections, which were marred by violence and irregularities, are seen as a test of Egypt's transition to democracy. The Muslim Brotherhood and other Islamist parties have called for mass protests on January 25 to demand the military council to hand over power to a civilian government. The trial of Mubarak and his sons is expected to shed light on the corruption and abuses of power that characterized Mubarak's regime. The outcome of the parliamentary elections and the trial will have significant implications for Egypt's political future.
answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.

Two separate incidents made headlines in Mendon, Massachusetts, this week. In the first event, a car driven by Nabila Altahan was suspended from a telephone pole after a sudden GPS instruction caused her to swerve off the road and up the guy wire on Wednesday evening. The incident occurred around 8 p.m. near the Sugar Maple Mini Golf Course on Route 143. Altahan and her passenger were unharmed in the accident. According to police reports, Altahan had passed her intended destination when her GPS device instructed her to turn around. In reaction to the directions, she swerved to the right, leaving the road and striking the telephone pole. Witnesses at the scene reported seeing Altahan jump out of the car before it was lifted off the ground. Emergency responders from both the State Police and Rutland City Fire Department arrived at the scene to ensure the safety of those involved.

In the second news item, no specific details were provided, but it was reported that a man was arrested in Mendon on Thursday for allegedly driving under the influence of drugs. The man's identity was not disclosed in the brief report. The incident occurred on Route 143, the same road where the car was suspended from the telephone pole the previous evening. No further information was available at the time of the report.

Both incidents caused disruptions on Route 143, with the car accident resulting in the closure of the road for several hours while emergency crews worked to remove the vehicle and restore service to the affected telephone line. The cause of the man's arrest is still under investigation.
answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
